data.title: Is the deprecation message for deprecated selectors correct?
data.body: ### Description I have a **question** about a deprecation message that is shown for my atom package. The function `transformDeprecatedShadowDOMSelectors` produces the following deprecation message for my package [code-annotations](https://atom.io/packages/code-annotations): ``` Starting from Atom v1.13.0, the contents of atom-text-editor elements are no longer encapsulated within a shadow DOM boundary. This means you should stop using :host and ::shadow pseudo-selectors, and prepend all your syntax selectors with syntax--. To prevent breakage with existing style sheets, Atom will automatically upgrade the following selectors: - code-annotation-container .hidden => code-annotation-container .syntax--hidden - ... ``` The message is talking about `syntax selectors`. I am not sure what exactly that means. I would understand these selectors as being contained in an `atom-text-editor` element. My package adds elements to the `atom-pane`. Therefore they are not descendants of an `atom-text-editor`: Accordingly my package's selectors only affect elements in my `code-annotation-container` and are (in my understanding) NOT syntax selectors. So my question is **Should I update my selectors according to the deprecation message (and if yes, why) or is the message incorrect in my case?** ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Download the `code-annotations` package 2. Reload the window 3. Open the Deprecation Cop **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions Atom: 1.18.0 (probably for all version >= 1.13.0) OS: macOS Sierra (10.12.5)

data.title: Auto-complete doubles up on typed input.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After auto-complete is selected, it will retype the initial input that brought up the auto-complete.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new file.
2. Select a language that supports auto-complete.
3. Begin typing until auto-complete suggestion is brought up.
4. Select one of the suggestions.

**Expected behavior:** 
Auto-complete should complete the text according to the selected option.

**Actual behavior:**
Auto-complete doubles on the typed input.

![issue-p1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20100206/27762644-226ea7b4-5e2b-11e7-9f37-1478bbce0556.gif)

![issue-p2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20100206/27762660-390161ce-5e2b-11e7-85d2-0b2a3ca16d27.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%

### Versions
Atom         :1.18.0
Electron    :1.3.15
Chrome     :52.0.2743.82
Node         :6.5.0

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

macOS Sierra 10.12.5

data.title: atom.commands.onDidFinish
data.body:
### Description of the Change

adds an `atom.commands.onDidFinish` function that is called after commands actually finish.

This will require commands that are asynchronous to return a promise so onDidFinish can know when a command is still working asynchronously.

### Alternate Designs

This comes from trying to return a commands value in #14720 

I decided to go with a `did-finish` event to keep backwards compatibility and use the event emitter already attached to `atom.commands`

This event is emitted once `Promise.all` on the return values of the command listeners finishes. Therefore it will be emitted when all listeners are resolved or one listener is rejected. And only the dispatched event is provided. A couple things could be changed here:

- We could wait until all listeners are resolved or rejected.
- We could emit a different event if rejected.
- We could include the returned values of the commands.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

It requires changes to the command registry and package creators to return a promise if the command is async.

### Benefits

- Ability to tell when an async command actually finishes.
- Ability to dispatch commands in series.

### Possible Drawbacks

Package creators will need to come on board for this to be very usefull

### Applicable Issues

#13195

data.title: Invalidate block decoration dimensions automatically when their size changes
data.body:
Supersedes https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14844.
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14836.

In the previous implementation of the editor rendering layer, we used to continuously re-measure block decorations that were on-screen. This was done to allow users to interact with the decorations, without requiring any extra work by package authors if the decorations size changed dynamically as a response to user input. During the rewrite in #13880 we lost this behavior and issues like the one linked above started arising. 

With this pull-request, we will now automatically schedule a new update when detecting that a block decoration got resized and call `invalidateBlockDecorationDimensions` on behalf of package authors. This is powered by a per-component `ResizeObserver` that listens for size changes on every added block decoration.

data.title: Poor performance on Ubuntu on HiDPI/UHD display
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom's performance is fairly poor on my laptop running Ubuntu GNOME 17.04 on a UHD display (3840x2160). Opening files or settings bumps up CPU usage, and when Atom is maximized, scrolling is quite choppy and runs the CPU up as well. When I change my resolution down to 1920x1080, it performs perfectly.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0
```

data.title: Atom does not detect the correct PATH.
data.body:
### Description

Atom is not inheriting the correct `PATH` for my system.

Terminal:
```
$ echo $PATH
/Applications/Zed.app/bin:/Users/ryan.mcquen/.local/bin:/usr/local/php5/bin:/usr/local/php5-5.6.30-20170506-093822/bin:/usr/local/Homebrew/bin:/opt/X11/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/opt/X11/bin:/Library/TeX/texbin:/Applications/Zed.app/bin:/Users/ryan.mcquen/.local/bin:/Users/ryan.mcquen/bin:/usr/local/php5/bin:/usr/local/php5-5.6.30-20170506-093822/bin:/usr/local/Homebrew/bin
```
Atom:
```
process.env.PATH
"/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin"
```
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run Atom.
2. Check your `PATH` (`process.env.PATH` in the Dev Tools Console).
3. See the lack of your `PATH`.

**Expected behavior:** Atom would report the same `PATH` as `echo $PATH` in my terminal.

**Actual behavior:** Atom seems to be using the default system `PATH`.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.17.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```

Mac OS 10.11.6.

### Additional Information

I'm using `tmux`.

data.title: [Feature request] Save position in Packages window when going into plugin settings
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I'm working with a list of plugins - whether installing a new plugin or going through settings or current plugins, or whatever, I'll be scrolling down a lengthy list, then I'll select one (or its settings), which will take me into the plugin's settings.  Now...  I want to go back to the list **to the place in the list where I just was - not at the beginning of the list!!!!**) It's kind of a pain to have to remember where I was and re-scroll back there every single time.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Pull up any lengthy list of plugins - whether by search or by having a bunch of plugins listed
2. Scroll somewhere in the middle or toward the end of the list
3. Click on settings for a plugin
4. Try to go back to where you were before

**Expected behavior:** There should be some way to go back to the list and be where you just were in the list.  OR have the settings for the given plugin open in a new tab.  

**Actual behavior:** This doesn't happen

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions

All

### Additional Information

data.title: Dock toggle rendering issue
data.body:
### Prerequisites

_Note: Unable to reproduce in safe mode._

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The Dock toggles will sometimes develop a rendering glitch, causing a bar to appear around the button.

### Steps to Reproduce (_Updated_)

1. Install the `docks-test` package found here: [docks-test.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1109683/docks-test.zip)
2. Install `atom-material-ui`. Tested with v2.0.4.
3. Open a file.

**Expected behavior:**

No graphical bugs with the Dock item.

**Actual behavior:**

When the "flow in" animation for the Dock toggle finishes a rectangular shaped region of the screen as high as the button but much wider will appear colored in the `@app-background-color` (I think), sometimes it will have content from the status bar showing in the bar. This status bar content is _not_ from the area "under" the bar, so it's not something that is getting translated up with the button.

"Normal" blank bar:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27649520-e67c8668-5be6-11e7-896d-38285a96c1b9.png)

Status bar content:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27649153-d0a616a2-5be5-11e7-9b60-f0499731681a.png)

GIF:
![2017-06-28_09-48-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27649602-1607e576-5be7-11e7-9487-c512ba257bf7.gif)

Note that with the updated steps to reproduce the behavior is actually worse than shown in the screenshots as the window starts out with a glitched rendering bar:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27652328-239b7a78-5bf0-11e7-83ac-a714a4f3488f.png)

There is actually a line number hidden behind the bar as well, as can be seen (briefly) in this GIF:
![2017-06-28_10-55-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27652371-4b9adafa-5bf0-11e7-9978-912ad8265ab2.gif)


**Reproduces how often:**

Almost all windows seem to eventually show this behavior, but I can't determine a reliable way to reproduce this.

- I can't seem to replicate in safe mode, or with a stock theme (One Dark).
- I use `atom-material-ui` with One Dark Syntax.
- ~~This _might_ be dependent on `linter-ui-default`,~~ but it may just be that that is the only bottom Dock item that I usually have running.
- I only ever see a brief flash of the right side Dock toggle showing this when Atom is loading, once loaded I don't see it from that toggle.

### Versions

 I've seen this since at least v1.18.0 betas, possibly since v1.17.0 betas.

Currently seeing this in:
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

Related issues:
https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/344
https://github.com/steelbrain/linter/issues/1501

<details>
<summary>Here is a list of installed packages</summary>

```
atom-autocomplete-php@0.25.6
atom-beautify@0.30.3
atom-jade@0.3.0
atom-material-syntax@1.0.6
atom-material-syntax-dark@1.0.0
atom-material-syntax-light@0.4.6
atom-material-ui@2.0.4
atom-typescript@11.0.4
autocomplete-lua@0.8.2
autocomplete-python@1.9.1
busy-signal@1.4.3
docblockr@0.10.5
editorconfig@2.2.2
file-watcher@1.1.0
fizzy@0.21.0
flow-ide@1.5.0
highlight-selected@0.13.1
intentions@1.1.2
language-ansible@0.2.1
language-babel@2.66.0

data.title: npm WARN enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory - when installing packages
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I recently updated to 1.18 with the Windows installer - note I am running as a non-Administrator on a corporate system. This changed the way I had previously installed to now installed in `$HOME\AppData\Local` which is great. My existing packages survived, but I was getting  errors when updating packages. I also cannot install packages. I can reproduce this reliably and I have reset to factory defaults (removed `.atom\`) and this problem persists.

The error appears to be related to the failed creation of the "apm-install" directory under `$HOME\AppData\Local\Temp\`.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click `Install` on any community package
2. Wait

**Expected behavior:** Package installs

**Actual behavior:** Install fails

**Reproduces how often:** 92.732%

This might reproduce 40 times in a row, then work 4 in a row. 

### Versions

`>atom --version`
> 
>Atom    : 1.18.0
>Electron: 1.3.15
>Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
>Node    : 6.5.0

`>apm --version`
>apm  1.18.1
>npm  3.10.10
>node 6.9.5 x64
>python
>git
>visual studio

### Additional Information

Error output from failed install:

> Installing “vim-mode-plus@0.93.0” failed.Hide output…
> C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi
> `-- (empty)
> 
> 
> npm WARN enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, open 'C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi\package.json'
> npm WARN apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi No description
> npm WARN apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi No repository field.
> npm WARN apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi No README data
> npm WARN apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi No license field.
> npm ERR! Windows_NT 10.0.10586
> npm ERR! argv "C:\\Users\\username\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.18.0\\resources\\app\\apm\\bin\\node.exe" "C:\\Users\\username\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.18.0\\resources\\app\\apm\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "C:\\Users\\username\\.atom\\.apm\\.apmrc" "--userconfig" "C:\\Users\\username\\.atom\\.apmrc" "install" "C:\\Users\\username\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\d-117528-20320-15ra7t7.j2pxecdi\\package.tgz" "--runtime=electron" "--target=1.3.15" "--arch=x64" "--global-style"
> npm ERR! node v6.9.5
> npm ERR! npm  v3.10.10
> npm ERR! path C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi\node_modules\vim-mode-plus
> npm ERR! code EPERM
> npm ERR! errno -4048
> npm ERR! syscall rename
>

> npm ERR!     at moveAway (C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.18.0\resources\app\apm\node_modules\npm\lib\install\action\finalize.js:38:5)
> npm ERR!     at destStatted (C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.18.0\resources\app\apm\node_modules\npm\lib\install\action\finalize.js:27:7)
> npm ERR!     at C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.18.0\resources\app\apm\node_modules\npm\node_modules\graceful-fs\polyfills.js:267:18
> npm ERR!     at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:123:15)
> npm ERR! 
> npm ERR! Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, rename 'C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi\node_modules\vim-mode-plus' -> 'C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi\node_modules\.vim-mode-plus.DELETE'
> npm ERR!     at Error (native)
> npm ERR!  Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, rename 'C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi\node_modules\vim-mode-plus' -> 'C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\apm-install-dir-117528-20320-xdopcx.9igkl0udi\node_modules\.vim-mode-plus.DELETE'

data.title: 1.19.0-beta2: Cursor stucks at the first letter when using macOS Chinese IME
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Cursor stuck at the first letter when using macOS built-in Chinese pinyin IME. 

We expect to input some characters first, and choose a word in IME panel. But from 1.19.0 (maybe beta 1), the cursor always stucks at the first letter. Although I can still type Chinese correctly under the circumstances., it is more helpful to see what you are typing out.

### Steps to Reproduce

**Expected behavior:** 

In 1.18.0, it looks well.

![atom](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14314532/27643849-ccf636da-5c54-11e7-9111-e7b09469cf10.gif)


**Actual behavior:** 

However, the cursor moves no more in 1.19.0-beta2.

![atom-beta](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14314532/27643959-0f04396e-5c55-11e7-838c-ac15ef580fbe.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** every time

### Versions

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.5
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Information

At first, I dived into source code to search for the problem. Soon, I overwhelmed with the large codebase of Atom. I cannot figure out which commit producing this bug. If anyone can point out which part may produce this problem, I can help to solve it. Thanks :)

data.title: Settings lost
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Sometimes when updating packages, Atom loses most of its settings. E.g. right now, I updated Hyperclick, and after the restart I was greeted with the welcome message, my font was reset to the default settings, my settings for linter-pycodestyle and linter-pylint were lost, and I assume all the others as well, but I didn't bother with the rest much, so no impact there in my case.

This is difficult to reproduce; I can update packages dozens of times, but every once in a while, it loses all my settings. It's not a disk full issue, as I have 56GB available.

The data loss appears to be limited to the things in ~/.atom/config.cson - the other .cson files and styles.less appear to be unaffected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Update packages
2. Restart

**Expected behavior:** Atom restarts with upgraded packages, and settings intact.

**Actual behavior:** Atom restarts with upgraded packages, and lost settings.

**Reproduces how often:** Less than 10%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1

OS: Linux Mint 17.3 Rosa
Kernel: 3.19.0-32-generic #37~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Oct 22 09:41:40 UTC 2015 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: [Feature request] Support YAML as configuration format along with JSON/CSON
data.body:
YAML has several obvious advantages:

  * Comparing CSON it's language agnostic and widespread (build systems, etc)
  * Comparing JSON it supports comments and has neat more "human readable" syntax

I would be cool to have it before crucial #5168

data.title: Atom 1.18 (32 bits) build fails on Fedora 24: "Failed to mmap ELF file [...]"
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * ~Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode~
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * ~Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages~

### Description

I got this error on building Atom 1.18.0: **`Error: Failed to mmap ELF file '[...]/out/app/node_modules/superstring/build/Release/superstring.node': Invalid argument
Failed to write symbol file.`**

> _Entire output at the end of post._

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install dependencies: `sudo dnf --assumeyes install make gcc gcc-c++ glibc-devel git-core libsecret-devel rpmdevtools libX11-devel libxkbfile-devel`
2. Run `script/build --create-rpm-package`

**Expected behavior:** Get the `atom-1.18.0-0.1.fc24.i686.rpm` installer.

**Actual behavior:** Build error.

**Reproduces how often:** 4 of 4

```
Node:	v6.10.3
Npm:	v3.10.5
```

 :---:sdNMMMMNds:------------:        RAM: 903MiB / 1987MiB
 :------:://:-------------::

        throw new Error(error)
        ^

Error: Error: Failed to mmap ELF file '/home/nmartell/sources/fedora-atom-builder/sources/atom/out/app/node_modules/superstring/build/Release/superstring.node': Invalid argument
Failed to write symbol file.

  at /home/nmartell/sources/fedora-atom-builder/sources/atom/script/lib/dump-symbols.js:26:15
  at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (/home/nmartell/sources/fedora-atom-builder/sources/atom/script/node_modules/minidump/lib/minidump.js:37:7)
  at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)
  at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:191:7)
  at maybeClose (internal/child_process.js:886:16)
  at Socket.<anonymous> (internal/child_process.js:342:11)
  at emitOne (events.js:96:13)
  at Socket.emit (events.js:188:7)
  at Pipe._handle.close [as _onclose] (net.js:497:12)
```

data.title: Only expect a single 'did-destroy' event
data.body:
These events will only be fired a single time at most, so we should clean up the listeners after that.

This should help minimize accidental memory leaks.

cc @hansonw

data.title: Atom Github 2FA not working in Atom (1.18.0)
data.body:
### Description

So excited as i was, i wanted to see the new github feature. After my commit and stuff, i wanted to push my code to github, which asks for a username/password. If i fill in the form with the correct username/password i get a password invalid. 

I figured it had to do something with 2FA, so i disabled it. 
After disabling is, it works like a charm, except that my accounts isn't safe.

If you could fix the issue, i'll try to add my SSH key to see if i can work around the issue. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable 2FA
2. Push to repo
3. try to login.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
I expected Atom to push my new code

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
I stuck on the login screen

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% of the time.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS: OSX Sierra, 10.12.5 (16F73)
Macbook pro touchbar

### Additional Information

None
